thread.title: Rangers take lead on bizarre play in Game 5 of ALDS
thread.title_full: Rangers take lead on bizarre play in Game 5 of ALDS

title: Rangers take lead on bizarre play in Game 5 of ALDS
text:
Job Link Video Rangers take lead on bizarre play in Game 5 of ALDS (Frank Gunn/The Canadian Press via AP). Home plate umpire Dale Scott, left, signals for Texas Rangers' Rougned Odor to score after conferring with the base umpires to confirm an error by Toronto Blue Jays catcher Russell Martin (not shown) on the play ... (Nathan Denette/The Canadian Press via AP). Toronto Blue Jays manager John Gibbons argues with the umpires after a call during the seventh inning in Game 5 of baseball's American League Division Series against the Texas Rangers, Wednesday, Oct. 14, 201... (Frank Gunn/The Canadian Press via AP). Texas Rangers' Rougned Odor celebrates with teammates after scoring on an error Toronto Blue Jays catcher Russell Martin (not shown) during the seventh inning in Game 5 of baseball's American League Division Seri... (Nathan Denette/The Canadian Press via AP). Texas Rangers' Rougned Odor, left, celebrates with Prince Fielder after scoring a run during the seventh inning in Game 5 of baseball's American League Division Series against the Toronto Blue Jays, Wednesday... (Nathan Denette/The Canadian Press via AP). A grounds crew member collects beer cans thrown on to the field after the Texas Rangers scored a run during the seventh inning in Game 5 of baseball's American League Division Series, Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2015... 
TORONTO (AP) - A deflected throw back to the mound by Toronto catcher Russell Martin allowed Texas to score the tiebreaking run in the seventh inning, touching off a long delay and causing the Blue Jays to play Game 5 of the AL Division Series under protest. 
Fans littered the field with debris during the 18-minute delay as umpires sorted out one of the most unusual plays in playoff history. 
With Odor at third base and two outs, Martin's throw back to the mound appeared to hit the hand of batter Shin-Soo Choo, allowing Odor to sprint home as the ball rolled up the third base line for a 3-2 lead. 
Home plate umpire Dale Scott initially ruled it a dead ball but, after Rangers manager Jeff Banister came out, the umpires huddled and Odor was sent home. 
According to rule Major League Baseball rule 6.03(a)(3), the batter is not to be charged with interfering with the catcher if the batter is still in the batter's box and doesn't make a movement to block or dirupt the throw. 
This type of play is not subject to manager's review but Scott, the crew chief, after discussing the ruling with Blue Jays manager John Gibbons, called an umpire's review. After a delay of 2 minutes, 32 seconds, the play stood and fans continued to throw objects on the field. 
Toronto Mayor John Tory tweeted, "Don't hurt each other or our city over this. We can prove ourselves in more ways than one. #ComeTogether" Copyright 2015 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.
